title: Coroner identifies 40-year-old man killed by train in Shafter - bakersfieldnow.com
content: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KBAK/KBFX) — The Kern County Coroner’s Office has identified a man who died after being struck by a train in Shafter on Saturday as 40-year-old Gerardo Becerra Perez.The report said on January 17, 2026, at around 9:34 a.m., Perez was found dead after being hit by a train on South Beech Avenue and East Los Angeles Avenue in Shafter.The report said he died at the scene.

title: Train Strikes and Kills Gerardo Perez in Shafter, Authorities Say - Accident Injury News
content:
Train Strikes and Kills Gerardo Perez in Shafter, Authorities Say

SHAFTER, CA — January 17, 2026 — A 40-year-old man was killed Saturday morning after being struck by a train in Shafter, according to authorities. The Kern County Coroner’s Office identified the victim as Gerardo Becerra Perez, a resident of Shafter. Law enforcement officials said Perez was hit by a train near the intersection of South Beech Avenue and East Los Angeles Avenue. Officers responded to the scene at approximately 9:34 a.m., where Perez was pronounced dead. The circumstances leading up to the collision were not immediately released, and the incident remains under investigation.



 Each year, hundreds of lives are lost in train-related incidents across the United States, many occurring at crossings with limited warning signs, faulty signals, or inadequate fencing. According to the National Safety Council, railroad fatalities reached 954 in 2024, reflecting a 1% decrease from the revised 2023 total of 967. Candice Bond, a seasoned train accident attorney, emphasized the importance of conducting an independent investigation promptly following a fatal crash to help preserve critical evidence for a victim’s family. “An experienced attorney can help shield grieving families from large railroad companies, which often deploy their own investigative teams and have extensive resources to defend against claims,” said Bond, Managing Partner of Bond Legal. “Acting quickly is crucial in these cases to ensure that all evidence is properly examined,” Bond added. 

 Pending the outcome of the investigation, surviving family members of Gerardo Becerra Perez may have the right to pursue a wrongful death claim. In such cases, families may seek compensation for loss of companionship, emotional distress, and the pain and suffering caused by the sudden loss of a loved one. “The emotional toll following the unexpected death of a family member can be devastating,” said Stefano Formica, Of Counsel with Bond Legal. “A wrongful death attorney can closely monitor the investigation while working to protect the legal rights and interests of the victim’s family,” Formica said.

title: Train Collides with SUV in Hesperia; Driver Escapes Unharmed - vvng.com
content:
HESPERIA, Calif. (VVNG.com) — A train struck an SUV Sunday evening in Hesperia, but the driver was able to escape moments before impact.
The incident was reported at approximately 6:13 p.m. on January 25, 2026, near the intersection of W. Santa Fe Avenue and Deodar Street.
A white SUV became disabled on the tracks and was struck by a BNSF freight train hauling tanker cars.
Emergency crews responded to the scene and determined that no injuries occurred as a result of the crash.
According to preliminary information, the driver of the SUV managed to exit the vehicle before it was hit.
It is believed the driver may have fallen asleep prior to the collision. Drugs or alcohol are not suspected to be factors in the incident.
Train traffic was temporarily halted while crews worked to remove the damaged vehicle from the tracks.
The investigation is being handled by BNSF Police, and no further details have been released.

title: Ontario, CA – Fatal Train Crash at E Airport Dr & N Archibald Ave - localaccidentreports.com
content:
Ontario, CA (January 25, 2026) – A deadly incident occurred late Saturday morning involving a train and a pedestrian near the intersection of East Airport Drive and North Archibald Avenue in the city of Ontario. Authorities responded to the scene shortly after 11:25 a.m. on January 24 following reports of a person struck on the tracks.

According to dispatch records, a Union Pacific train was involved in the fatal collision, which occurred within the jurisdiction of the California Highway Patrol’s Inland Division. The pedestrian, identified only as a trespasser at this time, was pronounced deceased at the scene. Responding officers requested the San Bernardino County Coroner’s Office shortly after confirming the fatality.

Officials have not released the identity of the victim, and it remains unclear how the individual came to be on the tracks. There is currently no estimated time for coroner arrival, and the area was temporarily held for investigation and scene management.

This tragic event remains under active investigation. Union Pacific and local law enforcement are working to determine the circumstances that led to the fatal encounter.

Our hearts go out to the family and loved ones of the individual who lost their life in this tragic incident.

title: Jamaal Scott dies in Ontario train accident, coroner says - The Legal Advocate
content:
Pedestrian fatally hit by train near Archibald Avenue and Airport Drive
ONTARIO, CA, (January 25, 2026) - A 43-year-old man tragically died Sunday morning in a train vs. pedestrian accident in Ontario, according to a coroner's press release from the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department.
Jamaal Scott died Sunday morning in a train vs. pedestrian accident near Archibald Avenue and Airport Drive in Ontario.
The report says Jamaal Lionel Scott was hit by a train near Archibald Avenue and Airport Drive at approximately 10:49 a.m.
Sadly, Scott was declared dead at the scene.
Additional details were not initially released.
The Ontario Police Department is investigating.
FATAL PEDESTRIAN TRAIN ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION
Train accidents such as this can occur for several reasons, including train personnel error, train track failure, a mechanical error or malfunction, a signalman error, and reckless actions. During the probe, investigators will also examine if the crash site was made safe for the pedestrian crossing.
According to the National Transportation Safety Bureau (NTSB), approximately 1,000 people are killed in train-related accidents each year.
Candice Bond, an experienced train accident attorney, said that in cases such as this that it is imperative to have an independent investigation conducted by a seasoned lawyer as soon as possible to preserve evidence for a victim's family.
“A skilled attorney can protect a grieving family from powerful train companies, which often send their investigators to crash sites and possess a variety of resources they can utilize to defend a negligent party,” said Bond, Managing Partner of Bond Legal and national analyst for The Legal Advocate.
WRONGFUL DEATH CLAIM
Pending results of the investigation, the family of Jamaal Scott may be entitled to a wrongful death claim. Family members of wrongful death victims may seek damages for loss of love and companionship, pain, suffering and emotional distress following a catastrophic accident such as this incident.
“The stress and sorrow can be extremely overwhelming after losing a loved one in an accident,” said Stefano Formica, Of Counsel with Bond Legal. “We understand just what families are forced to go through, and having their rights protected is vital. A wrongful death lawyer will stay updated on the official investigation and help ensure that their legal rights and best interests are protected.”

title: Pregnant woman killed in crash involving Metrolink train and car in Glendale - ABC7 Los Angeles
content:
Pregnant woman killed in crash involving Metrolink train and car in Glendale

GLENDALE, Calif. (KABC) -- A pregnant woman was killed Wednesday morning in a violent collision involving a Metrolink train and a car at a crossing in Glendale.

The crash was reported shortly after 9 a.m. on Brazil Street, just west of the intersection of San Fernando Road and Broadway, between the Burbank Downtown and the Glendale stations, according to Metrolink.

The victim was pronounced dead at the scene.

According to the Glendale Police Department, the sedan was traveling northbound on West San Fernando Road when the driver attempted to make a right turn onto Broadway, which turns into Brazil Street at that point.

"As the vehicle entered the crossing, it was struck by a Metrolink train traveling on the tracks," police said in a statement.

The downtown L.A.-bound train, number 206 on the Antelope Valley Line, was stopped on the tracks for hours after the collision.

A male pedestrian who was in the immediate area was struck by an object as a result of debris from the collision, police said. He was transported to a local hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

"There are approximately 150 passengers on train 206, though no injuries have been reported aboard at this time," Metrolink said in a statement issued shortly after 10 a.m.

Trains 207 and 208 on the Antelope Valley Line were canceled, as were trains 320 and 341 on the San Bernardino Line. Metro buses were used to shuttle passengers between the Burbank Downtown and Glendale stations.

The Glendale Police Department was leading the investigation.

City News Service contributed to this report.

title: Woman killed, 4 injured after Metrolink train collides with car in Glendale - FOX 11 Los Angeles
content:
Woman killed, 4 injured after Metrolink train collides with car in Glendale
GLENDALE, Calif. - Authorities are investigating a fatal crash involving a Metrolink train in Glendale that left a woman dead and several others injured on Wednesday.
What we know:
The incident was reported at approximately 9 a.m. on Brazil Street, situated just west of the intersection of San Fernando Road and Broadway.
According to the Glendale Police Department, the vehicle was traveling northbound on West San Fernando Road when the driver attempted to make a right turn onto Broadway, which turns into Brazil Street.
Once the car entered the crossing, it was struck by an oncoming Metrolink train, police said.
The victim, later identified by the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner as 35-year-old Zukhra Kurbanova, died at the scene.
Officials said around 150 passengers were on board at the time. Three passengers were injured, with one requiring hospitalization, authorities said.
A male bystander was also hospitalized after being struck by flying debris from the impact.
The incident led to the immediate cancellation of Trains 207 and 208 on the Antelope Valley Line, as well as Trains 320 and 341 on the San Bernardino Line.
To help stranded commuters, Metro buses were deployed to provide shuttle service between the Burbank Downtown and Glendale stations.
What's next:
The Glendale Police Department is leading the ongoing investigation into the crash.
The Source: This report is based on information from the Los Angeles Fire Department and the Glendale Police Department. City News Service contributed.

title: Metrolink train slams into car in Glendale, killing 1 person, hospitalizing 2 - Los Angeles Times
content: A Metrolink train traveling from the Antelope Valley to downtown Los Angeles slammed into a car Wednesday morning, killing one occupant of the car, according to authorities. Around 9 a.m., Metrolink Train 206 struck an occupied car between the Burbank and Glendale stations, according to Metrolink spokesperson Laurene Lopez. The crash occurred near San Fernando Road and West Broadway in Glendale. One occupant of the car died while another passenger and a bystander were hospitalized, Lopez said. Two passengers on the train were assessed and treated by the Glendale Fire Department and the Los Angeles County Fire Department. Coroner’s officials arrived around 11:50 a.m. and the tracks were still closed around noon, according to Lopez. The train was released to go into Glendale with passengers on board. The Glendale Police Department is the lead agency investigating the incident.Such collisions are rare but not unheard of.In June of last year, a semitruck collided with a Metrolink train in an agricultural area of Moorpark, killing the truck driver and sending one of the train passengers to the hospital, authorities said.In January 2025, a Metrolink train struck a car in the City of Industry, killing two people inside the vehicle, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Woman Killed, 4 Others Injured When Train Crashes into Car That Was Crossing Tracks - People.com
content:
A pregnant woman was killed, and four others were injured after a train slammed into a car that was crossing the tracks in California.

According to police in Glendale, Calif., a city bordering Los Angeles, the crash involved a Metrolink train that was traveling from the Antelope Valley to downtown Los Angeles at around 9 a.m. on Wednesday, Feb. 4.

Police said that a driver attempted to make a turn from the city's West San Fernando Road onto Broadway, crossing the railroad tracks.

As the car entered the railroad crossing, it was hit by Metrolink train 206, police wrote in a statement shared to Facebook.

Police and fire personnel were called to the scene, and the driver, identified as 35-year-old Zukhra Kurbanova, by authorities and FOX Los Angeles, was pronounced dead at the scene.

ABC7 and KTLA reported after the crash that Kurbanova was pregnant.

Additionally, police said that a man walking nearby was struck by debris. His injuries were not life-threatening, and he was taken to a local hospital.

Metrolink told the outlets that three passengers aboard the train also reported injuries, including one person who was hospitalized and two who were treated by emergency personnel on the train.

Footage from the local news outlets showed fire and police officials at the scene as the car, a silver sedan, sat on the tracks as the railroad's safety arms were down. The vehicle was heavily damaged, and its airbags were deployed.



"There are approximately 150 passengers on train 206, though no injuries have been reported aboard at this time," the rail operator told ABC7 in a statement.

The Los Angeles County Medical Examiner's Office told PEOPLE that the decedent was a resident of Glendale, and an exam has been scheduled.



When reached for comment, the Glendale Police Department said they could not release the identity of the deceased until the coroner's office's part of the investigation was complete.

"Additionally, this complex investigation will require some more time and our traffic investigator’s opinion as to why will be deferred until then," they added. "We do have knowledge that the arms at the tracks were in fact operational and operating at the time the driver made the right turn."



Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.



Trains 207 and 208 on the Antelope Valley Line were canceled for the day, Metrolink added, in addition to trains 320 and 341 on the San Bernardino Line. Instead of normal functions, buses were used to shuttle passengers to other stations.

content:

Ernesto Centeno Araujo

Man killed by Amtrak train in Somis identified
Authorities have identified the man who was killed by an Amtrak train in the unincorporated Somis area on Feb. 7.
Miguel Garcia Castillo, 25, was from Somis, according to the Ventura County Medical Examiner's Office. He died of blunt force head injuries and his death was deemed a suicide.

title: Indio Man Killed After Being Struck by Train, Authorities Say - NBC Palm Springs
content: A local alert this evening as authorities confirm that an Indio man has died after being struck by a train late last night.The Riverside County Coroner’s Office identified the victim as Noel Tapia of Indio. Officials say Tapia was hit by a train while on the tracks between Indio Boulevard and Hoover Street.The incident happened just after midnight, according to investigators. Emergency responders transported Tapia to a hospital in Palm Springs, where he later died from his injuries.A representative from Union Pacific Railroad said Tapia was trespassing on the tracks at the time of the incident for unspecified reasons.The circumstances surrounding why Tapia was on the tracks remain under investigation. Authorities have not released further details at this time.Officials continue to remind the public that railroad tracks are private property and can be extremely dangerous, urging residents to stay clear of train corridors at all times.

title: After Stockton derailment, California lawmaker pushes for tougher rail safety rules - CBS News
content:
After Stockton derailment, California lawmaker pushes for tougher rail safety rules
A California congressman is calling for more railroad oversight. It comes on the three-year anniversary of one of the nation's most destructive railway accidents and just a day after a derailment in Stockton.
Most of the 17,000 Pacific Gas and Electric customers now have power restored following Monday's train accident in the Stockton railyards. But that mishap highlights the impact a train derailment can have on nearby communities.
"Millions of Americans live and work along hazmat railways," said Ed Kelly, general president of the International Association of Firefighters. "We need to protect them."
This week marks the three-year anniversary of the fire and explosion in East Palestine, Ohio, that was caused by a train derailment.
Congressman John Garamendi says similar tanker cars carrying flammable chemicals regularly come through Davis, Sacramento, and other Northern California communities.
"And we've had our share of almost-serious accidents," Garamendi said.
He is co-sponsoring a bipartisan bill that would require new railroad safety standards.
"This rail safety bill covers sensible things," Garamendi said. "It's not complex, but it is very, very important."
It would mandate having at least two crew members on board trains. It also requires railroads to install defect detectors that can spot mechanical problems, and it would force railroads to fund more hazmat training for first responders.
"Too often, firefighters arrive at train derailments with limited information and limited training," Kelly said.
Penalties for safety violations would also be increased.
The Association of American Railroads says there's no proven safety benefit to justify the cost of requiring two crew members. They oppose these kinds of regulations and want to adopt modern technologies to enhance safety benefits.
But bill supporters say more work needs to be done to protect communities from any more railway disasters.
The authors of the bill are trying to get it included in a vote for the new federal surface transportation reauthorization act.

title: Santa Barbara County, CA – Man Hit, Injured by Freight Train near Lookout Park According to the authorities, the accident was reported just after 5 p.m. February 10, between Lookout Park and Fernald Point Santa Barbara County, CA – A man was hospitalize - facebook.com
content:
Santa Barbara County, CA – Man Hit, Injured by Freight Train near Lookout Park According to the authorities, the accident was reported just after 5 p.m. February 10, between Lookout Park and Fernald Point

Santa Barbara County, CA – A man was hospitalized after being hit by a freight train near Summerland in Santa Barbara County on Tuesday afternoon.

According to the authorities, the accident was reported just after 5 p.m. February 10, between Lookout Park and Fernald Point.

Firefighters with the Montecito Fire Protection District and other emergency personnel responded to the scene and found a pedestrian on the railroad tracks.

Preliminary reports indicate that a freight train had hit the victim but the circumstances under which the accident happened were yet to be established.

The victim was given first aid before being transported to Lookout Park. He was then loaded onto an AMR ambulance and taken Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital.

https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&opi=89978449&url=https://www.montecitofire.com/&ved=2ahUKEwj4v6z20dGSAxXs5ckDHQVpOVwQFnoECCAQAQ&usg=AOvVaw3PjfMXvgQhh0AIwPU5isjF As per the Montecito Fire () officials, the pedestrian was transported with serious injuries. There was no update on the victim’s identity at the time of the report.

The railroad tracks were temporarily shut down in the area while investigations into the incident were ongoing. The tracks had reopened as of 7 p.m.

Authorities are currently working to find out how and why the pedestrian was hit by the train.

title: Pedestrian Struck and Killed by Amtrak Train Near Milpas Street in Santa Barbara - edhat
content:
On February 1, 2026, at approximately 1:34 pm, The Santa Barbara Police Communications Center received a 9-1-1 call regarding an AMTRAK train that struck at pedestrian on Milpas Street at the railroad tracks.
Santa Barbara Police, Santa Barbara Fire and AMR Paramedics responded to the emergency. The pedestrian had tragically succumbed to their injuries. 
Milpas St is currently closed and will remain closed until the investigation can be completed and the train can be safely moved.
The deceased adult male’s identity is being withheld pending the notification of their next of kin.
This is a tragic incident, and the Santa Barbara Police Department would like to remind everyone to please use extreme caution when you are crossing the railroad tracks and please abide by the warning signals at the railroad crossings.
The Santa Barbara County Coroner’s Office responded to the scene and took over the investigation.

title: Community urges council to close train crossing after deaths - Palo Alto Daily Post
content:
Palo Alto community members are urging City Council to close the intersection where Churchill Avenue intersects with the railroad tracks after a Caltrain hit and killed 17-year-old Summer Devi Mehta last Tuesday.

In a letter to the City Council Nick Mehta, Summer’s father, said he supports closing the intersection, believing Churchill provided an “easy means for her to impulsively act at a low moment.”

The letter was read by a friend of Nick Mehta’s during tonight’s council meeting.

The Caltrain crossing at Churchill Avenue and Alma Street is adjacent to Palo Alto High School, and has been the site of multiple student suicides over the past few years.

“It is too late for my daughter but it is not too late for others,” Nick Mehta wrote.

In response, Mayor Vicki Veenker said tonight that an The Rail Safety/Youth Mental Health ad hoc committee has been created to look into ramping up safety measures at the intersection, and the logistics of shutting it down, an action that Palo Alto Unified School District Superintendent Don Austin urged the council to do in a Thursday letter.

The committee consists of council members Julie Lythcott-Haims, Pat Burt and Greer Stone.

Lythcott-Haims said the committee has already met with Caltrain and other city transportation safety officials to explore their options, which included talks about installing more high-tech cameras that can detect unusual movements on the tracks and paying security guards to monitor the intersection. The committee will meet again this week, Lythcott-Haims said.

But several residents said they also want council to shut the Churchill crossing immediately, and not wait for the committee’s insights and recommendation.

A resident who identified herself as Bre. T said her daughter was Summer’s friend and is “begging” the council to close the intersection.

“Failing to close is a complacency I just can’t tolerate as a mom anymore,” she said.

Prior to the ad hoc meeting, Caltrain and Palo Alto were working on installing new technologies at Churchill crossings to improve safety, including using AI to help detect and alert officials about lingering cars and pedestrians on the tracks. Other potential updates include a partial underpass to reduce car and pedestrian traffic and grade separation, which would require temporarily closing the crossing.

title: Woman killed, 4 injured after Metrolink train collides with car in Glendale - AOL.com
content:
One person was killed Wednesday morning when a Metrolink train collided with a vehicle at a crossing in Glendale.
• The crash occurred around 9 a.m. near San Fernando Road, leaving 150 passengers stranded and four others injured.
• Investigators have not yet determined why the vehicle was on the tracks or the identity of the victim.

GLENDALE, Calif. - Authorities are investigating a fatal crash involving a Metrolink train in Glendale that left a woman dead and several others injured on Wednesday.

What we know

The incident was reported at approximately 9 a.m. on Brazil Street, situated just west of the intersection of San Fernando Road and Broadway.

According to the Glendale Police Department, the vehicle was traveling northbound on West San Fernando Road when the driver attempted to make a right turn onto Broadway, which turns into Brazil Street.

Once the car entered the crossing, it was struck by an oncoming Metrolink train, police said.

The victim, later identified by the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner as 35-year-old Zukhra Kurbanova, died at the scene.

Officials said around 150 passengers were on board at the time. Three passengers were injured, with one requiring hospitalization, authorities said.

A male bystander was also hospitalized after being struck by flying debris from the impact.

The incident led to the immediate cancellation of Trains 207 and 208 on the Antelope Valley Line, as well as Trains 320 and 341 on the San Bernardino Line.

To help stranded commuters, Metro buses were deployed to provide shuttle service between the Burbank Downtown and Glendale stations.

The Glendale Police Department is leading the ongoing investigation into the crash.

This report is based on information from the Los Angeles Fire Department and the Glendale Police Department. City News Service contributed.

Pending results of the investigation, family members of Jose Calderon may be entitled to a wrongful death claim. Family members of wrongful death victims may seek damages for loss of love and companionship, pain, suffering and emotional distress following a catastrophic accident such as this incident.
“The stress and sorrow can be extremely overwhelming after losing a loved one in an accident,” said Stefano Formica, Of Counsel with Bond Legal. “We understand just what families are forced to go through, and having their rights protected is vital. A wrongful death lawyer will stay updated on the official investigation and help ensure that their legal rights and best interests are protected.”
(This report is based on verified data - learn more on our About Us page.)

title: Zukhra Kurbanova killed in Glendale Metrolink train crash, police say - The Legal Advocate
content:
Two people, including a bystander, were transported to a hospital
GLENDALE, CA, (February 04, 2026) - The Glendale Police Department said a 35-year-old woman was killed in a crash with a downtown Los Angeles-bound Metrolink train along Brazil Street on Wednesday morning.
Zukhra Kurbanova, 35, was killed Wednesday morning when her vehicle was struck by a downtown Los Angeles-bound Metrolink train at a crossing in Glendale.
She was identified by the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner as Zukhra Kurbanova.
The crash occurred just west of the intersection of San Fernando Road and Broadway.
Kurbanova was driving a vehicle northbound on West San Fernando when she attempted to make a right turn onto Broadway around 9 a.m. and was struck by a Metrolink train traveling on the tracks. Tragically, she died at the scene from her injuries. The train was carrying roughly 150 passengers, three of whom were injured. One person was transported to a hospital. A bystander struck by debris from the crash was also hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries.
Two trains, each on the Antelope Valley and San Bernardino lines, were canceled after the collision.
This is an ongoing investigation.
CRASH INVESTIGATION NEEDED
Train accidents such as this can occur for several reasons, including train personnel error, train track failure, a mechanical error or malfunction, a signalman error, and reckless actions.
Each year, train-related crashes claim hundreds of lives across the United States. Many of these fatalities result from poorly marked crossings, malfunctioning signals and inadequate fencing. Railroad deaths totaled 954 in 2024, a 1% decrease from the 2023 revised total of 967, the National Safety Council said in a report. During the probe, investigators will also examine if the crash site was made safe for the crossing.
Candice Bond, who specializes in train-related crashes, said that in cases such as this, it is imperative to have an independent investigation conducted by a seasoned lawyer as soon as possible to preserve evidence for a victim's family.
“A skilled attorney can protect a grieving family from powerful train companies, which often send their investigators to crash sites and possess a variety of resources they can utilize to defend a negligent party,” said Bond, Managing Partner of Bond Legal.
WRONGFUL DEATH CLAIM
Pending the investigation, the family members of Zukhra Kurbanova may be entitled to a wrongful death claim. Family members of wrongful death victims may seek damages for loss of companionship, pain, suffering, and emotional distress following a catastrophic accident such as this incident.
“The stress and sorrow can be extremely overwhelming after losing a loved one in an accident,” said Stefano Formica, Of Counsel with Bond Legal.
“We understand just what families are forced to go through, and having their rights protected is vital. A wrongful death lawyer will stay updated on the official investigation and help ensure that their legal rights and best interests are protected.”
(This report is based on verified data - learn more on our About Us page.)
Have you been in a similar accident and need help? Speak to one of The Legal Advocate's national legal analysts now free of charge for a no-obligation.

title: UPDATE: Pedestrian struck and killed by an Amtrak train in Santa Barbara - KSBY News
content:
UPDATE: As of this morning, Milpas Street is back open to drivers, according to the Santa Barbara Police Department. There are no additional details involving the incident, including the cause.

UPDATE (4:46 p.m.): According to the Santa Barbara Police Department, a man was struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Sunday afternoon.

The report was made at around 1:30 p.m., and crews from several agencies responded to the report. However, the man died from his injuries shortly. The identity of the man is being withheld until the family is notified.

Milpas Street is currently closed as crews investigate the incident and safely remove the train.

ORIGINAL STORY: As of Saturday afternoon, A portion of Milpas Street in Santa Barbara is closed due to a train crash involving a pedestrian. Officials with the Santa Barbara Police Department are advising drivers to avoid the street near the train tracks and use an alternate route until further notice.

title: Santa Barbara County, CA – Train Accident Injures Man Near Summerland - localaccidentreports.com
content:
Santa Barbara County, CA (February 12, 2026) – A man was seriously injured after being struck by a freight train between Lookout Park and Fernald Point near Summerland on Tuesday, February 10 just after 5 p.m., according to authorities.

Key Details

Reported: Tuesday, February 10 just after 5 p.m.

Tuesday, February 10 just after 5 p.m. Location: Railroad tracks between Lookout Park and Fernald Point, near Summerland

Railroad tracks between Lookout Park and Fernald Point, near Summerland Type of incident: Freight train versus pedestrian

Freight train versus pedestrian Injuries: Victim sustained serious injuries

Victim sustained serious injuries Medical response: Transported by AMR ambulance to Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital

Transported by AMR ambulance to Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital Responding agency: Montecito Fire Protection District and other emergency personnel

What We Know So Far

Firefighters located the injured pedestrian on the railroad tracks upon arrival.

Preliminary reports indicate a freight train struck the man under circumstances that remain under investigation.

The victim received first aid before being moved to Lookout Park and then transported to the hospital.

Rail service in the area was temporarily shut down and reopened around 7 p.m.

What’s Not Yet Confirmed

How the pedestrian came to be on the tracks at the time of the collision.

The identity of the injured man.

Whether any warning systems or signals were activated prior to the incident.

The man’s current medical condition.

Local Context

The incident occurred along the coastal railroad corridor between Lookout Park and Fernald Point near Summerland in Santa Barbara County. This stretch of track runs close to shoreline communities and recreational areas, including Lookout Park, and is used regularly by freight and passenger trains traveling through the region. When a train-related injury is reported in this area, responders from agencies such as the Montecito Fire Protection District must coordinate access along the tracks, which can be more difficult than roadway incidents. Temporary rail shutdowns may also affect service schedules while authorities secure the scene and conduct their investigation.

What to Do Next

If you witness a rail-related emergency, call 911 immediately and provide the exact location, including nearby landmarks such as Lookout Park or Fernald Point. Remain at a safe distance from railroad tracks and avoid attempting to approach or assist unless directed by emergency personnel. Write down what you observed, including train direction and timing, while the details are still fresh. Check official transit or rail advisories for updates if you plan to travel through the affected corridor.

FAQ

Q: Why are details sometimes limited right after a train accident?

A: Early information is often preliminary while investigators review scene evidence, speak with train operators and witnesses, and confirm the sequence of events.

Q: Are train-pedestrian crashes typically severe?

A: Collisions involving trains often result in serious injuries due to the size and speed of rail equipment, which can limit stopping distance.

Q: Can railroad operations be suspended after an incident?

A: Yes. Rail traffic may be temporarily halted so emergency crews can safely assist victims and investigators can examine the scene before service resumes.

title: Man Injured In Incident At LAXs Still-Unopened People Mover Train: Report - Patch
content:
Crime & Safety
Man Injured In Incident At LAX's Still-Unopened People Mover Train: Report
A man was injured in an incident involving LAX's automated people mover on Thursday.
LOS ANGELES, CA — A man was injured in an incident involving the Los Angeles International Airport’s still-unopened automated people mover train on Thursday, according to a report.
The Los Angeles Fire Department responded to the airport after 1 p.m. Thursday in response to the incident, in which a 36-year-old man suffered minor injuries. He was transported to a local hospital, according to KTLA.
The man was believed to have been working on the people mover when the incident happened.
Find out what's happening in Los Angelesfor free with the latest updates from Patch.
When complete, the people mover will transport passengers between terminals at LAX and connect to a Metro transit center, parking and rental car center. The train has been subjected to delays and is now set to open later this year.
Get more local news delivered straight to your inbox. Sign up for free Patch newsletters and alerts.

title: Person Taken to Hospital After Being Hit by Train Near Santa Barbara Cemetery - Noozhawk
content:
A man died Friday night after being struck by a train near the Santa Barbara Cemetery, according to the Santa Barbara Police Department.
Personnel from the Santa Barbara City Fire Department and the Montecito Fire Protection District responded shortly after 5:45 p.m. to the report of a train-versus-pedestrian collision near the 1800 block of East Cabrillo Boulevard, fire Battalion Chief Jon Turner told Noozhawk.
Police officers also responded and started CPR, which was taken over by fire crews, Turner said.
The victim, who was found on the south side of the tracks, was transported by AMR ambulance to Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries, police said.
His name was not released pending notification of relatives.
Responders confirmed the victim was hit by a northbound Amtrak passenger train, Turner added.
The incident was under investigation and no other information was immediately available.
This is the third incident of a person being hit and injured by a train in southern Santa Barbara County this month.
A man was struck and killed by a northbound Amtrak Pacific Surfliner train on Feb. 1 in Santa Barbara near Milpas Street. The Coroner’s Bureau is investigating and has not yet released his name.
On Tuesday, a man was transported to the hospital with major injuries after being hit by a freight train in Summerland. The man was hit on a trestle on the tracks between Lookout Park and Fernald Point.

title: Man dead after train collision in Montecito - News Channel 3-12
content:
MONTECITO, Calif. (KEYT) – Montecito Fire crews helped take a man to the hospital after a train hit him near the City Sanitation District on the south side of the tracks.

The man did not survive after an Amtrak train hit him just before 6:00 p.m., according to the Montecito Fire Department.

Santa Barbara Police, among others, tried to use CPR on the man before they took him to Cottage Hospital where he unfortunately passed away.

The man's name is being withheld pending notification of the next of kin, according to the SBPD.

title: Early-Morning Train Collision Involves Stuck Vehicle - The E’ville Eye
content:
A vehicle was struck by a train early Saturday morning in Emeryville after a driver accidentally turned onto the railroad tracks near 67th and Shellmound and became stuck, police said.

The collision occurred around 1:09 a.m. on February 14, prompting a response from emergency personnel. According to the Emeryville Police Department, the female driver was able to safely exit the vehicle before an oncoming train struck it. The vehicle caught fire following the impact.

No injuries were reported, and authorities said all involved parties remained on scene and cooperated with the investigation. Police noted there were no signs of impairment and DUI was not suspected.

Rail service in the area was temporarily shut down for several hours while crews worked to extinguish the fire, remove the vehicle, and conduct a full inspection of the tracks. The vehicle was cleared without further incident, and officials emphasized there was no threat to the public.

Emeryville police thanked Union Pacific Railroad and the Alameda County Fire Department for their coordinated response.

Authorities also reminded residents that if a vehicle becomes stuck on train tracks, drivers should call 911 immediately so emergency personnel can halt rail traffic and respond quickly.
